C. Erlanger. After a meeting with
Dean Berry, Holt Maulsby, President
of the S. A. C., announced Erlanger
as his successor, and at the same
time named John Royster and Herbert Rydstrom as being recommended
to the offices of Senior and Junior
Representative, respectively.
Each of the three men will be appointed, as is traditionally the case,
by the President of the University,
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, on the Dean's
recommendation.
Of the two present Junior members, Erlanger has been named for
the presidency for 1937-38, and
Royster Senior secretary. The three
members of the present board (the
two above mentioned and Maulsby)
unanimously approved Herbert Rydstrom
as Junior Representative.
Rydstrom, now in his sophomore year,
has just been elected Junior President of the Musical Club. He has
been associated with that organization for the past two years.
Holt Maulsby, now passing out of
office, echoes an optimistic note for
next year's Student Activities Committee saying:
"With the selection of Herbert
Rydstrom as the Junior Representative, Billy Erlanger as President,
and John Royster as Secretary, I feel
certain that the committee for next
year will be the strongest in the history of the organization."

ject

Finkel and Philip Grossman, won the
Junior-Senior Debate held in Latrobe
Hall yesterday. The debate had not
been held for several years, and yes.
terday marked the revival of this
traditional rivalry.
Prior to the debate, both sides had
agreed upon a definition of neutrality
as meaning no military alliances in
peace or war, and no commerce
whatsoever with any nation engaged
in war. The affirmative was upheld
by Merel Hamel and Morris Zucker,
juniors. Dr. Broadus Mitchell, Dr.
John
Calvin
French, and
Dr.
Johannes Mattern acted as judges.
Wasserman Presides
Mr. Earl Wasserman, chairman
and coach for the Debating Council,
sponsor of the contest, announced
prior to the debate that a prize of
fifteen dollars is awarded each man
on the winning side. There were two
constructive speeches and two refutations delivered for each side.
The Affirmative team contended
that "if we would really stay out of
other people's wars, we must fight
against it as against a disease: with
quarantine!" They also outlined a
plan for neutrality.
Neutrality Cause Of War
The Negative team, upholding its
stand, gave numerous examples of
the effect of such a neutrality program in causing, rather than eliminating warfare. The neutrality plan
was shown to be a factor which
would enmesh the United States in
foreign warfare.
The debate was concluded with the
delivery of the refutations and rendering of the judges' decisions.

Signing Of Band Makes June
Week Definite; Large
Support Needed

6, and 7 in the Hullabaloo office to
all those who have signed up for the
year book.
For those who will be out of town
on these dates, the Hullabaloo has
arranged to have the book mailed to
these persons, provided that they give
twenty-five cents to Mr. Myers in the
post office, on or before June 5. Anyone, however, who has signed for the
book, although he has failed to pay
his quarter, may get the Hullabaloo
in the fall. A book will be reserved
for everyone to whom one is due.
Kramer also declared that all those
who have signed for the book, and
have failed to pay for it, have had
the money deducted from their caution fees. The price for the book is
$10 for Seniors, and $3.30 for anyone else.
At the same time, it was revealed
that nominations for the Board of
Control had been held Wednesday.
The following men were nominated:
Theodore Schad and Nathaniel Soifer
for editor-in-chief; Robert Weiss and
Merel Harmel for business manager;
and Philip Perel for photographic
editor. These and other nominations
will be acted upon by the present
Board of Control on Monday, May 17.
On the following Wednesday, the final
elections will be held.

Dazzling Edythe Wright
Edythe Wright scored a sensation
on her visit to the Hopkins campus
for the Cotillion Board dance last
Thanksgiving.

From all reports,
Miss Wright is just nineteen .. . five-

feet-five ... and, if she hasn't changed
recently, she has soft, glimmering
auburn hair that curls fetchingly
over ever-smiling eyes of brown.
The Annapolis Roads Clue will be
the scene of the annual beach party
on Saturday, June 5. The party will
start in the morning and last far
into the night. Music will be provided by a well-known local orchestra
Attempts are being made by the
Junior Prom Committee to obtain
Dick Messner and his orchestra for
the Prom on Wednesday, June 2. At
the time of this writing Hal Ke.mp
was the likely band to be signed for
the Senior Ball on Thursday, June 3.
The tariff for the complete June
Week program is ten dollars. Two
dollars and twenty-five cents is being
charged for a separate admission to
the Interfraternity Ball — stag or
couple.

Tudor And Stuart
Elects Nine Members
On Monday afternoon, the Tudor
and Stuart Club held Its spring meeting for the election of new members.
The following were chosen for the
new members: Mr. Leigh Hunt and
Mr. J. B. Linton, from the graduate
English
students;
Herbert
Armstrong, L. Wethered Barroll, Paul
W. B. Berge, J. Murray Kempton,
Bill Lamble, George Mitchell and
Frazier Yearly, from the undergraduates.
The new members will attend their
first formal meeting on Friday night,
when the annual business meeting
will be held. The meeting will be
followed by an informal smoker in
the Club rooms.

to non-athletic extra-curricular activities. In order to facilitate a judicial distribution, the Committee
assists the Ibusiness managers of the
various activities in drawing up their
financial budgets. It is the purpose
of the committee to supervise all expenditures in the endeavor to follow
the proposed budgets as closely as
possible. This year the Committee
inaugurated a system of requisitions
which has proven to be an important
factor in the checking of all disbursements.
The Dean's Advisory Committee on
Student Activities, which is the full
name of the S.A.C., is the successor
to the Student Activities Council,
and has, consequently, taken over
the duties of that organization. The
Council, which consisted of the heads
of all the activities, and was too large
and unwieldy to be efficient, was reorganized at the instigation of the
Board of Trustees of the University
in 1934. Since this change in organization, graft in the activities has
been eliminated, and all transactions
have been carried out in a much
more orderly and business-like fashion. Other functions of the Committee include assistance in drawing
up and amending constitutions of
the activities and supervising the
elections in an effort to enforce observance of these constitutions and
to minimize unfair politics. This year,
the Committee offered a set of
standardized election by - laws to
the activities which will again be
presented for approval to the new
officers of the activities for next
year. The purpose of these by - laws
was to simplify election procedures
and to attempt to give every candidate for membership or office a
square deal. Finally, the Student
Activities Committee awards the
Varsity Seal to those men who have
given three years of active service
to extra - curricular activities.
The members of the Committee
are appointed annually by the President of the University on the recommendation of the Dean. An effort
is made to select men whose integrity
is beyond question, and who have
proven themselves efficient in an
understanding of the activities in
which they have taken a part.

In Organization

"The same forces which brought
the world into the last war, which
kept the world from making peace,
are leading the world straight into
another war. That is an inevitable
fact!" asserted Dr. Harry F. Ward,
of Union
Theological Seminary,
speaking before the members of the
"Y" Supper Club last Tuesday night.
"There has been no attempt to
check the forces leading to war. A
"Fascist International" has been created, and is at present fighting it
out in Spain. The United States and
Great Britain are directly and indirectly aiding the cause of Spanish
Fascists, and the very word 'neutrality' in the neutrality bill is a deception," he said.
Dr. Ward feels that the present
economic prosperity is based almost
entirely on the increased manufacture of armaments, and is not a true
prosperity. He attacked the Neutrality Bill, on the grounds that it
applied sanctions against the legitimate Spanish government.

Dr. Robert B. Roulston, editor-inchief of the Johns Hopkins alumni
magazine for 20 years, has recently
resigned. Dr. Roulston's resignation,
according to the Alumni Association,
followed a request from Dr. Roulston
that he be relieved from the exacting
duties of the office in view of his long
tenure in office.
The resignation, which was accepted by the Alumni Association, is
to be effective with the issuance of
the August number, sometime this
summer. As yet, no new editor has
ben appointed, and at the present
time a temporary committee is guiding the destiny of the magazine.
At the same time, Mr. Thomas
Hubbard,- secretary of the organization, revealed several major changes
in the Alumni Association organization. A committee, appointed last
year and headed by E. Guy Stapleton,
studied the set-up, and issued a report
which defined the purpose of the association, and recommended changes •
In the organization. The report has
been accepted by the association as
a pattern for its development.
It dealt with the raising of funds
by the organization, and alumni activities. At the last meeting, the
following officers of the association
were elected: J. A. Dushane Penniman, president; Guy F. Hollyday,
vice-president; Thomas F. Hubbard,
secretary; and Horace E. Flack,
treasurer.

After last Tuesday's engagement
with Catholic University, the Blue
Jay cindermen stored away their
spiked shoes until next spring. This
year's season was rather unsuccessful save for the impressive showing
at the annual Mason-Dixon meet.
Yet, there are many bright aspects,
particularly due to the rapid improvement among the large majority
of freshmen. It is upon this group
that Coach Hambleton hopes to construct his future track luminaries.
The major loss from this year's
aggregation will be Ted Graziano,
stocky captain, who has been a consisent point gainer in several
events.

Pete Hughes, president of the Hopkins Chapter of the Spiked Shoe Society, announced that six new men
have been officially named to this national honorary track organization.
These men, who have shown excellent
athletic ability plus a deep-felt interest in track, were inducted into
the group last night at a formal
meeting at which Paul Castelle was
elected president for next year.
Once each year the Spiked Shoe
Society sponsors an interscholastic
long distance run that generally attracts the leading schoolboy distancemen.

To Tackle

After having tasted two unpleasant
defeats at the hands of Princeton
and St. John's, the Hopkins lacrossemen will attempt to regain their early
season form against the West Point
hickory handlers. The future generals are rated as the outstanding
northern ten, even superior to the
clawing Tiger. They have scored impressive victories over Yale and
Syracuse.
Always excellently conditioned, the
Cadet attack is a smooth working
machine. There are two complete
sets of men available for combat at
every post and they have consistently
outrun the defense of all opposition.
Scott and Sollohub are outstanding
In scoring ability; both are elusive
dodgers, clever stick-handlers, and
accurate shot-producers. Sherburne,
Posey, and Spragin, all husky and
dangerous, generally are in the contest at the start. Truxtun starts the
play at the center face-off from his
pivot post.

to well-aimed shots. Army's defense is

and Clark. In typical fashion, these
men press their "man" at all time,
rushing shots and hurrying passes.

Gay, Edwards, Maloney, Crawford,
Boliord, Hoisington, Johnson, Tomhave, Smith, Lane and Meyer.

C. Erlanger. After a meeting with
Dean Berry, Holt Maulsby, President
of the S. A. C., announced Erlanger
as his successor, and at the same
time named John Royster and Herbert Rydstrom as being recommended
to the offices of Senior and Junior
Representative, respectively.
Each of the three men will be appointed, as is traditionally the case,
by the President of the University,
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, on the Dean's
recommendation.
Of the two present Junior members, Erlanger has been named for
the presidency for 1937-38, and
Royster Senior secretary. The three
members of the present board (the
two above mentioned and Maulsby)
unanimously approved Herbert Rydstrom
as Junior Representative.
Rydstrom, now in his sophomore year,
has just been elected Junior President of the Musical Club. He has
been associated with that organization for the past two years.
Holt Maulsby, now passing out of
office, echoes an optimistic note for
next year's Student Activities Committee saying:
"With the selection of Herbert
Rydstrom as the Junior Representative, Billy Erlanger as President,
and John Royster as Secretary, I feel
certain that the committee for next
year will be the strongest in the history of the organization."

Finkel and Philip Grossman, won the
Junior-Senior Debate held in Latrobe
Hall yesterday. The debate had not
been held for several years, and yes.
terday marked the revival of this
traditional rivalry.
Prior to the debate, both sides had
agreed upon a definition of neutrality
as meaning no military alliances in
peace or war, and no commerce
whatsoever with any nation engaged
in war. The affirmative was upheld
by Merel Hamel and Morris Zucker,
juniors. Dr. Broadus Mitchell, Dr.
John
Calvin
French, and
Dr.
Johannes Mattern acted as judges.
Wasserman Presides
Mr. Earl Wasserman, chairman
and coach for the Debating Council,
sponsor of the contest, announced
prior to the debate that a prize of
fifteen dollars is awarded each man
on the winning side. There were two
constructive speeches and two refutations delivered for each side.
The Affirmative team contended
that "if we would really stay out of
other people's wars, we must fight
against it as against a disease: with
quarantine!" They also outlined a
plan for neutrality.
Neutrality Cause Of War
The Negative team, upholding its
stand, gave numerous examples of
the effect of such a neutrality program in causing, rather than eliminating warfare. The neutrality plan
was shown to be a factor which
would enmesh the United States in
foreign warfare.
The debate was concluded with the
delivery of the refutations and rendering of the judges' decisions.

At the same time, it was revealed
that nominations for the Board of
Control had been held Wednesday.
The following men were nominated:
Theodore Schad and Nathaniel Soifer
for editor-in-chief; Robert Weiss and
Merel Harmel for business manager;
and Philip Perel for photographic
editor. These and other nominations
will be acted upon by the present
Board of Control on Monday, May 17.
On the following Wednesday, the final
elections will be held.

Tudor And Stuart
Elects Nine Members
On Monday afternoon, the Tudor
and Stuart Club held Its spring meeting for the election of new members.
The following were chosen for the
new members: Mr. Leigh Hunt and
Mr. J. B. Linton, from the graduate
English
students;
Herbert
Armstrong, L. Wethered Barroll, Paul
W. B. Berge, J. Murray Kempton,
Bill Lamble, George Mitchell and
Frazier Yearly, from the undergraduates.
The new members will attend their
first formal meeting on Friday night,
when the annual business meeting
will be held. The meeting will be
followed by an informal smoker in
the Club rooms.

to non-athletic extra-curricular activities. In order to facilitate a judicial distribution, the Committee
assists the Ibusiness managers of the
various activities in drawing up their
financial budgets. It is the purpose
of the committee to supervise all expenditures in the endeavor to follow
the proposed budgets as closely as
possible. This year the Committee
inaugurated a system of requisitions
which has proven to be an important
factor in the checking of all disbursements.
The Dean's Advisory Committee on
Student Activities, which is the full
name of the S.A.C., is the successor
to the Student Activities Council,
and has, consequently, taken over
the duties of that organization. The
Council, which consisted of the heads
of all the activities, and was too large
and unwieldy to be efficient, was reorganized at the instigation of the
Board of Trustees of the University
in 1934. Since this change in organization, graft in the activities has
been eliminated, and all transactions
have been carried out in a much
more orderly and business-like fashion. Other functions of the Committee include assistance in drawing
up and amending constitutions of
the activities and supervising the
elections in an effort to enforce observance of these constitutions and
to minimize unfair politics. This year,
the Committee offered a set of
standardized election by - laws to
the activities which will again be
presented for approval to the new
officers of the activities for next
year. The purpose of these by - laws
was to simplify election procedures
and to attempt to give every candidate for membership or office a
square deal. Finally, the Student
Activities Committee awards the
Varsity Seal to those men who have
given three years of active service
to extra - curricular activities.
The members of the Committee
are appointed annually by the President of the University on the recommendation of the Dean. An effort
is made to select men whose integrity
is beyond question, and who have
proven themselves efficient in an
understanding of the activities in
which they have taken a part.

In Organization

"The same forces which brought
the world into the last war, which
kept the world from making peace,
are leading the world straight into
another war. That is an inevitable
fact!" asserted Dr. Harry F. Ward,
of Union
Theological Seminary,
speaking before the members of the
"Y" Supper Club last Tuesday night.
"There has been no attempt to
check the forces leading to war. A
"Fascist International" has been created, and is at present fighting it
out in Spain. The United States and
Great Britain are directly and indirectly aiding the cause of Spanish
Fascists, and the very word 'neutrality' in the neutrality bill is a deception," he said.
Dr. Ward feels that the present
economic prosperity is based almost
entirely on the increased manufacture of armaments, and is not a true
prosperity. He attacked the Neutrality Bill, on the grounds that it
applied sanctions against the legitimate Spanish government.

Dr. Robert B. Roulston, editor-inchief of the Johns Hopkins alumni
magazine for 20 years, has recently
resigned. Dr. Roulston's resignation,
according to the Alumni Association,
followed a request from Dr. Roulston
that he be relieved from the exacting
duties of the office in view of his long
tenure in office.
The resignation, which was accepted by the Alumni Association, is
to be effective with the issuance of
the August number, sometime this
summer. As yet, no new editor has
ben appointed, and at the present
time a temporary committee is guiding the destiny of the magazine.
At the same time, Mr. Thomas
Hubbard,- secretary of the organization, revealed several major changes
in the Alumni Association organization. A committee, appointed last
year and headed by E. Guy Stapleton,
studied the set-up, and issued a report
which defined the purpose of the association, and recommended changes •
In the organization. The report has
been accepted by the association as
a pattern for its development.
It dealt with the raising of funds
by the organization, and alumni activities. At the last meeting, the
following officers of the association
were elected: J. A. Dushane Penniman, president; Guy F. Hollyday,
vice-president; Thomas F. Hubbard,
secretary; and Horace E. Flack,
treasurer.

years or so ago, Dr. Willis R.

Whitney, now Vice President in charge of
General Electric research, sent a note to a
research worker, suggesting experiments with
a motor-generator set sealed gastight and filled
with hydrogen to see if the machine ran cooler,
and more efficiently. The results of those
eiperiments promoted the use of hydrogen in
synchronous condensers and established the
present trend toward the use of hydrogen in
turbine-generators.

thirty-three G-E employees. These thirtythree were selected from the 60,000 persons in
the Company's employ to receive the Charles
A. Coffin Awards. There were fifteen factory
men,. twelve engineers, two commercial men,
and four administrative and clerical employees.
Twelve of the group are college graduates:

Windage loss in a rotating machine is reduced
about 90 per cent and noise is greatly decreased
because of the low density of hydrogen. Heat
is carried away much more rapidly through the
higher thermal conductivity of hydrogen.
Resistance to damage due to corona within the
machine is increased. These characteristics
increase the electrical output for a given core
size and reduce inspection and maintenance
expense.

After last Tuesday's engagement
with Catholic University, the Blue
Jay cindermen stored away their
spiked shoes until next spring. This
year's season was rather unsuccessful save for the impressive showing
at the annual Mason-Dixon meet.
Yet, there are many bright aspects,
particularly due to the rapid improvement among the large majority
of freshmen. It is upon this group
that Coach Hambleton hopes to construct his future track luminaries.
The major loss from this year's
aggregation will be Ted Graziano,
stocky captain, who has been a consisent point gainer in several
events.

Pete Hughes, president of the Hopkins Chapter of the Spiked Shoe Society, announced that six new men
have been officially named to this national honorary track organization.
These men, who have shown excellent
athletic ability plus a deep-felt interest in track, were inducted into
the group last night at a formal
meeting at which Paul Castelle was
elected president for next year.
Once each year the Spiked Shoe
Society sponsors an interscholastic
long distance run that generally attracts the leading schoolboy distancemen.

This will close the fourth year of
interclass softball. Mr. Reuben Baer,
director, announced that this year
was the best for organized and fine
playing. The number of necessary
play-offs only emphasizes this fact.
With the end of softball, activities
will be suspended until the fall. Then,
the popular touch football league will
again be organized.

Stickmen
To Tackle
Army
After having tasted two unpleasant
defeats at the hands of Princeton
and St. John's, the Hopkins lacrossemen will attempt to regain their early
season form against the West Point
hickory handlers. The future generals are rated as the outstanding
northern ten, even superior to the
clawing Tiger. They have scored impressive victories over Yale and
Syracuse.
Always excellently conditioned, the
Cadet attack is a smooth working
machine. There are two complete
sets of men available for combat at
every post and they have consistently
outrun the defense of all opposition.
Scott and Sollohub are outstanding
In scoring ability; both are elusive
dodgers, clever stick-handlers, and
accurate shot-producers. Sherburne,
Posey, and Spragin, all husky and
dangerous, generally are in the contest at the start. Truxtun starts the
play at the center face-off from his
pivot post.

Strong Defense
In the goal is Connor, who is poison
to well-aimed shots. Army's defense is
manned by Tincher, Smith, Bradley
and Clark. In typical fashion, these
men press their "man" at all time,
rushing shots and hurrying passes.
Ready as replacements are Amick,
Gay, Edwards, Maloney, Crawford,
Boliord, Hoisington, Johnson, Tomhave, Smith, Lane and Meyer.
